ma81:1.2: One time, the Buddha traveled to the country of Aṅga with a large group of monks.
ma81:1.3: They went to Āpaṇa and stayed at Kaineya’s residence.
ma81:2.1: After the night passed and the sun rose, the Bhagavān put on his robe and took his bowl into Āpaṇa to solicit alms.
ma81:2.2: When his meal was finished, he put away his robe and bowl, washed his hands and feet, put his sitting mat over his shoulder, and went into a grove in the afternoon.
ma81:2.3: Going into that grove, he spread out his sitting mat under a tree and sat cross-legged there.
ma81:3.1: At the time, a large group of monks had gathered in the discussion hall after the midday meal, and they were conversing about this topic:
ma81:3.2: “Good men, the Bhagavān is rare and extraordinary.
ma81:3.3: He cultivates mindfulness of body and discerns and disseminates it.
ma81:3.4: He has the highest knowledge, highest observation, highest cultivation, and highest discipline.
ma81:3.5: Well-perfected in good conduct and residing in a unified mind, the Buddha teaches that mindfulness of body has great rewards and attains the vision and eyes to see the supreme truth.”
ma81:4.1: Just then, the Bhagavān was sitting in repose and used the divine ear that transcends that of humans to hear the monks gathered in the discussion hall.
ma81:4.2: After the midday meal, they were conversing about this topic:
ma81:4.3: “Good men, the Bhagavān is rare and extraordinary.
ma81:4.4: He cultivates mindfulness of body and discerns and disseminates it.
ma81:4.5: He has the highest knowledge, highest observation, highest cultivation, and highest discipline.
ma81:4.6: Well-perfected in good conduct and residing in a unified mind, the Buddha teaches that mindfulness of body has great rewards and attains the vision and eyes to see the supreme truth.”
ma81:4.7: After hearing this, the Bhagavān then got up from his repose in the afternoon, went to the discussion hall, prepared his seat in front of the monks, and sat down.
ma81:5.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
ma81:5.2: “What topic have you been discussing together?
ma81:5.3: What was the reason you gathered here in the discussion hall?”
ma81:6.2: “Bhagavān, we monks gathered here in the discussion hall after the midday meal to discuss this topic:
ma81:6.3: ‘Good men, the Bhagavān is rare and extraordinary.
ma81:6.4: He cultivates mindfulness of body and discerns and disseminates it.
ma81:6.5: He has the highest knowledge, highest observation, highest cultivation, and highest discipline.
ma81:6.6: Well-perfected in good conduct and residing in a unified mind, the Buddha teaches that mindfulness of body has great rewards and attains the vision and eyes to see the supreme truth.’
ma81:6.7: Bhagavān, we’ve been discussing this topic together.
ma81:6.8: This was the reason we gathered here in the discussion hall.”
ma81:7.1: The Bhagavān again addressed the monks,
ma81:7.2: “How do I teach the cultivation of mindfulness of body and discern and disseminate it?
ma81:7.3: What great rewards does it attain?”
ma81:8.1: The monks then said to the Bhagavān,
ma81:8.2: “The Bhagavān is the Dharma root, the Bhagavān is the Dharma lord, and the Dharma comes from the Bhagavān.
ma81:8.3: May it please him to discuss it.
ma81:8.4: After hearing it, we’ll get a detailed knowledge of its meaning.”
ma81:9.3: I will discern its meaning for you.”
ma81:10.1: The monks then accepted the teaching and listened.
ma81:11.2: “How does a monk cultivate mindfulness of body?
ma81:11.3: A monk walks and knows he’s walking.
ma81:11.4: He stands and knows he’s standing, sits and knows he’s sitting, and lies down and knows he’s lying down.
ma81:11.5: He sleeps and knows he’s sleeping, wakes and knows he’s waking, and he sleeps and wakes and knows he has slept and woke up.
ma81:12.1: “Thus, a monk follows his physical actions, knowing the above as it truly is.
ma81:12.2: If he thus goes into seclusion and lives alone, his thoughts aren’t careless.
ma81:12.3: He cultivates diligence, stops mental disturbances, and attains a concentrated state of mind.
ma81:12.4: After attaining a concentrated state of mind, he then knows the above as it truly is.
ma81:12.5: This is called a monk who cultivates mindfulness of body.
ma81:13.1: “Furthermore, a monk cultivates mindfulness of body.
ma81:13.2: That monk correctly knows that he’s exiting and entering, and he well observes and discerns that he’s bending and stretching high and low.
ma81:13.3: His manner is peaceful, and he wears his outer and other robes and carries his bowl well.
ma81:13.4: He’s correctly aware when walking, standing, sitting, lying, sleeping, waking, speaking, and being silent.
ma81:14.1: “Thus, a monk follows his physical actions, knowing the above as it truly is.
ma81:14.2: If he thus goes into seclusion and lives alone, his thoughts aren’t careless.
ma81:14.3: He cultivates diligence, stops mental disturbances, and attains a concentrated state of mind.
ma81:14.4: After attaining a concentrated state of mind, he then knows the above as it truly is.
ma81:14.5: This is called a monk who cultivates mindfulness of body.
ma81:15.1: “Furthermore, a monk cultivates mindfulness of body.
ma81:15.2: That monk produces mindfulness of what’s bad and unwholesome.
ma81:15.3: He subdues and extinguishes it with mindfulness of what’s good.
ma81:15.4: He’s like a carpenter or a carpenter’s apprentice who ties wood together with a cord and then chops off the excess with a sharp ax to make a straight [edge].
ma81:15.5: Thus, the monk produces mindfulness of what’s bad and unwholesome, and he subdues and extinguishes it with mindfulness of what’s good.

ma81:17.2: That monk puts his teeth together, presses his tongue up against his palate, and uses his mind to govern his thoughts, subduing and extinguishing them.
ma81:17.3: It’s like when two strong men arrest a weak man.
ma81:17.4: They go from place to place holding, controlling, and disciplining him.
ma81:17.5: Thus, that monk puts his teeth together, presses his tongue against his palate, and uses his mind to govern his thoughts, subduing and extinguishing them.

ma81:19.2: That monk is mindful of inhaling and knows he’s mindful of inhaling.
ma81:19.3: He’s mindful of exhaling and knows he’s mindful of exhaling.
ma81:19.4: He inhales long and knows he’s inhaling long.
ma81:19.5: He exhales long and knows he’s exhaling long.
ma81:19.6: He inhales short and knows he’s inhaling short.
ma81:19.7: He exhales short and knows that he’s exhaling short.
ma81:19.8: He trains while inhaling with his whole body and trains while exhaling with his whole body.
ma81:19.9: He trains while calming physical action as he inhales and trains while calming verbal action as he exhales.

ma81:21.1: “Furthermore, a monk cultivates mindfulness of body.
ma81:21.2: That monk’s body is wet and moistened by joy and happiness that arises from seclusion.
ma81:21.3: It thoroughly fills what’s in his body.
ma81:21.4: There’s nowhere that that joy and happiness that arises from seclusion doesn’t reach.
ma81:21.5: It’s like when a bath worker fills a dish with soap and mixes it with water to make a ball.
ma81:21.6: The water wets, moistens, and thoroughly fills it.
ma81:21.7: There’s nowhere that it doesn’t reach.
ma81:21.8: Thus, a monk’s body is wet and moistened by joy and happiness that arises from seclusion.
ma81:21.9: It thoroughly fills what’s in his body.
ma81:21.10: There’s nowhere that that joy and happiness that arises from seclusion doesn’t reach.

ma81:23.4: There’s nowhere that that joy and happiness that arises from concentration doesn’t reach.

ma81:23.6: On all four sides, there’s nowhere [more] water can enter.
ma81:23.7: From the bottom of that spring, the water spontaneously wells up and flows out to wet and moisten the mountain and thoroughly fill it.
ma81:23.8: There’s nowhere that it doesn’t reach.

ma81:27.2: What’s in that monk’s body is filled with the accomplishment of the mental freedom of a pure mind.
ma81:27.3: There’s nowhere in his body that that pure mind doesn’t reach.
ma81:27.4: He’s like a person wearing a seven- or eight-cubit robe.
ma81:27.5: From head to toe, there’s no part of his body that isn’t covered.

ma81:29.2: That monk is mindful of the perception of light.
ma81:29.3: That mindfulness is well-acquired, well-maintained, and well-intended.
ma81:29.6: As during the day, it’s likewise at night.
ma81:29.7: As during the night, it’s likewise during daytime.
ma81:29.10: Thus, he isn’t mistaken, and his mind has no fetters.
ma81:29.11: He cultivates a radiant mind, and his mind is never covered by darkness.

ma81:33.2: That monk follows this body’s loveliness and ugliness from head to toe according to its abiding.
ma81:33.3: He observes the various ways it’s filled with impurities.

ma81:33.5: He’s like a man with eyes to look at a container full of various seeds.
ma81:33.6: He discerns them clearly as rice, millet, barley, wheat, large and small sesame, oilseed, and mustard seed.

ma81:35.6: ‘In this body of mine, there’s the element of earth, element of water, element of fire, element of air, element of space, and element of consciousness.’

ma81:47.1: “If someone thus cultivates mindfulness of body and thus disseminates it, good qualities will be fully present in them, which are the factors of the path.

ma81:48.1: “If there’s an ascetic or priest who doesn’t correctly establish mindfulness of body and travels around with little thought, then Māra Pāpīyān can surely get an advantage over them.
ma81:48.3: It’s because that ascetic or priest is empty and lacks mindfulness of body.
ma81:48.4: They’re like a clay pot that’s empty and lacks water when it’s correctly placed [upright] on the ground.
ma81:48.5: If someone were to bring water and pour it into the pot, what do you monks think?

ma81:49.4: It’s empty and lacks water, and it’s correctly placed [upright] on the ground.
ma81:49.5: It therefore will surely accept it.”

ma81:66.1: “Thus cultivating mindfulness of body and thus disseminating it should be known to have 18 virtues.
ma81:66.3: That monk can endure hunger, thirst, cold, heat, biting insects, stinging insects, the oppression of sun and wind, and terrible noises.
ma81:66.4: He can also endure being caned.
ma81:66.5: When he experiences ailments and extreme pain such that his life is about to end, he’s able to tolerate these discomforts.
ma81:66.6: This is the first virtue of someone who thus cultivates mindfulness of body and thus disseminates it.
ma81:67.2: If he becomes unhappy, his mind never attaches to it.
ma81:67.3: This is the second virtue of someone who thus cultivates mindfulness of body and thus disseminates it.
ma81:68.2: If he becomes frightened, his mind never attaches to it.
ma81:68.3: This is the third virtue of someone who thus cultivates mindfulness of body and thus disseminates it.
ma81:69.1: “Furthermore, a monk produces the three bad thoughts, which are thoughts of desire, thoughts of anger, and thoughts of harmfulness.
ma81:69.2: If these three bad thoughts arise, his mind never attaches to them.
ma81:69.3: This is the fourth virtue of someone who thus cultivates mindfulness of body and thus disseminates it.
ma81:70.1: “Furthermore, that monk parts with desire and parts with bad and unwholesome things … and attains the accomplishment of the fourth meditation.
ma81:70.2: This is the fifth … eighth virtue of someone who thus cultivates mindfulness of body and thus disseminates it.
ma81:71.1: “Furthermore, once he has ended the three bonds, that monk becomes a stream entrant and doesn’t fall into bad states.
ma81:71.2: He’s certainly destined for right awakening and will experience at most seven existences.
ma81:71.3: After seven rebirths up in heaven or among humans, he’ll reach the limit of suffering.
ma81:71.4: This is the ninth virtue of someone who thus cultivates mindfulness of body and thus disseminates it.
ma81:72.1: “Furthermore, once he ends the three bonds, and lust, hate, and delusion are weakened, that monk attains one rebirth up in heaven or among humans.
ma81:72.2: After one rebirth, he will then reach the limit of suffering.
ma81:72.3: This is the tenth virtue of someone who thus cultivates mindfulness of body and thus disseminates it.
ma81:73.1: “Furthermore, that monk ends the five lower bonds.
ma81:73.2: He’ll be born elsewhere and then [enter] parinirvāṇa.
ma81:73.3: He attains irreversibility and doesn’t return to this world.
ma81:73.4: This is the eleventh virtue of someone who thus cultivates mindfulness of body and thus disseminates it.
ma81:74.1: “Furthermore, if he has calm liberation, that monk parts with form and attains formlessness.
ma81:74.2: According to that manner of concentration, he personally accomplishes its realization.
ma81:74.3: He observes and knows the contaminants and ends the contaminants with wisdom.
ma81:74.4: This is the twelfth virtue of someone who thus cultivates mindfulness of body and thus disseminates it.
ma81:75.7: Attaining the absence of contaminants, his mind is liberated, and his wisdom is liberated.
ma81:75.8: In the present life, he knows and recognizes for himself the accomplishment of self-realization:
ma81:75.9: ‘Birth has been ended, the religious practice has been established, and the task has been accomplished.’
ma81:75.10: He is no longer subject to existence and knows is as it really is.
ma81:75.11: This should be known as the thirteenth … eighteenth virtue of someone who thus cultivates mindfulness of body and thus disseminates it.
ma81:75.12: These should be known as the eighteen virtues of someone who thus cultivates mindfulness of body and thus disseminates it.”
ma81:76.2: Those monks who heard what the Buddha taught rejoiced and handed it down.
